title: A secret-video scandal brought down Sebastian Kurz's government. Now he's set to return
text:
(CNN) Austrians voted in a snap election on Sunday after Sebastian Kurz and his right-wing coalition government lost a vote of no confidence in May, following a corruption scandal prompted by a secretly-filmed video.

Initial projections published by Austrian public broadcaster ORF suggest Kurz's party, the conservative People's Party (ÖVP), is on track to be the largest in the Austrian parliament, with about 37% of the vote.

The far-right Freedom Party of Austria (FPÖ) is projected to receive 16%. That's significantly fewer votes than in the 2017 elections, when it received 26% of the vote.

People's Party (ÖVP) leader Kurz, who at 33 is one of the world's youngest leaders, was the first Austrian Chancellor since World War II to be defeated by a motion of no confidence.

The vote was triggered after Kurz's government became embroiled in a political crisis over an undercover recording. The secretly filmed video showed Vice Chancellor Heinz-Christian Strache -- of the Freedom Party of Austria (FPÖ) -- appearing to offer state contracts to a woman falsely claiming to be the niece of a Russian oligarch.

Read More
description: Austrians voted in a snap election on Sunday after Sebastian Kurz and his right-wing coalition government lost a vote of no confidence in May, following a corruption scandal prompted by a secretly-filmed video.
